title: 1920 Calculus Horror
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The consumption of coal by the 1920's steamer "},{"type":"text","text":"Ayumo","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" may be represented by the formula   "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y=0.3+0.001v^{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":",  where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" represents number of tons of coal burned per hour and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"v"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" represents speed in nautical miles per hour. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Other costs of maintenance of ship and wages, per hour, is same as cost 1 ton of coal."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What speed (in nautical mules per hour) will minimize the  total cost of a voyage of 1000 nautical miles? "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Bonus:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" What will be that minimum cost of voyage if 1 ton of coal = 10 shillings"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned}
&\text{Tons of fuel consumption per hour } = 0.3 + 0.001v^3 +1 = 1.3 + 0.001v^3 \\
&\text{The total distance of journey is 'd = 1000 nautical miles'. Total time of journey } = \frac{1000}{v} hrs \\
&\text{Total fuel consumed during journey = } \frac{1000}{v} \times (1.3 + 0.001v^3) = \frac{1300}{v} + v^2 \\ 
&\text{Cost of journey C(v) } = 10\times \Big(\frac{1300}{v} + v^2\Big) = \frac{13000}{v} + 10v^2 \\
&\text{For minimum cost C'(v) = 0}\\
&\Rightarrow \frac{-13000}{v^2} +20 v = 0 \\
 &\Rightarrow v^3 = 650 \\
&v = 8.66239 \text{ nautical miles per hour}\\
&\text{To check if v=8.66 is minima, C''(v) > 0 }  \\
&C''(v) = \frac{26000}{v^3} +20 \Rightarrow C''(650^{\frac{1}{3}}) = 60 >0 \\
&\text{Hence v = 8.66239 is the mimima} \\
\end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I think that should be a homework for the solvers or do you think should I do that as well?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Set to lvl 3. Your solution is almost complete. To prove that it's minimum, you need to show that C''(cube root of 650) is positive.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

Also level down the problem level. Its over rated

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":"@Anshuman Bais"}],"attrs":[{"profile":"https://brilliant.org/profile/anshuman-wxlfr0/"}]},{"type":"text","text":" It should be made clear in the term itself, that we are calculating the "},{"type":"text","text":"hourly consumption","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":", and not the implied total consumption.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

title: 1936's Year Problem.
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In a brilliant family, a fantastic event occurred in 1936's year. In this year, Tommy's age are the same as last two digits of the year that he born, and, coincidentally, the same occurred with him father's age. In this conditions, in 1936, what would be the sum of the age of Tommy and his father?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"At first, we don't know the decade nor year, but we can stipulate an century.
So, consider that the father borned in 1800's. So, we know that an age are measured by: (Actual year - Year born ). Thus, we have, for the father:
( D= dicker number, U= unit number)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1936 - (1800 + D  +U) = D + U "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"136 = 2D + 2U"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"68 = D + U "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, the father has 68 years old."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, for Tommy:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1936 - (1900 + D + Y) = D + U"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"36 = 2D + 2U"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"18 = D + U "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, tommy has 18 years."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus, the sum of their age is : 
68+18 = 86."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 1973rd non-perfect square
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find the 1973rd non-perfect square."}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Clarification:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" Non-perfect squares are positive integers which cannot be expressed as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is an integer. For example: 2, 3, 5, 7, 8,... and 2 is the first non-perfect square."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"q(n)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"th non-perfect integer. Then the sequence of non-perfect integers up to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"q(n)=k^2 +1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"th perfect square is as follows:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} \{ q(n) \} & = \underbrace{ {\color{#D61F06}\cancel 1}, 2, 3, {\color{#D61F06}\cancel 4}, 5, 6, 7, 8, {\color{#D61F06}\cancel 9}, 10, \cdots {\color{#D61F06}\cancel {k^2}}, k^2+1}_{k^2+1-k \text{ terms}} \\ \implies n & = k^2 - k + 1 \\ q(k^2-k+1) & = k^2 + 1 \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now the largest perfect square smaller than 1973 is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lfloor \sqrt {1973}\rfloor =44"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Then, we have: "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} q(k^2-k+1) & = k^2+1 & \small \color{#3D99F6} \text {Putting }k=44 \\  q(44^2-44+1) & = 44^2+1 \\ q(1893) & = 1937 \\ q(1893+80) & = 1937+80 \\  q(1973) & = \boxed{2017} \end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
